result.markdown: --- title: "Activity32" format: live-html: theme: light: [lux, theme-light.scss] dark: [superhero, theme-dark.scss] engine: knitr toc: true --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Prepare data with proper time index cement <- aus_production %>% select(Quarter, Cement) %>% as_tsibble(index = Quarter) # Split into train/test sets train <- cement %>% filter(year(Quarter) < 2005) test <- cement %>% filter(year(Quarter) >= 2005) ``` ::: ## Fitting Comparable ETS Models Let's compare some ETS specifications including: 1. Simple exponential smoothing (no trend/seasonality) 2. Holt's linear trend method 3. Holt-Winters seasonal method ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ets_models <- train %>% model( Simple = ETS(Cement ~ error("A") + trend("N") + season("N")), Holt = ETS(Cement ~ error("A") + trend("A") + season("N")), HW = ETS(Cement ~ error("A") + trend("A") + season("A")), HWM = ETS(Cement ~ error("A") + trend("A") + season("M")), HWMM = ETS(Cement ~ error("A") + trend("M") + season("M")) ) ``` ::: ## Forecast Evaluation Framework We'll evaluate using multiple metrics: - **MSE**: Mean Squared Error (penalizes large errors) - **MAE**: Mean Absolute Error (more robust) - **MAPE**: Mean Absolute Percentage Error (scale-independent) - **MASE**: Mean Absolute Scaled Error (relative to naive forecast) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Generate forecasts fc <- ets_models %>% forecast(h = "5 years") fc %>% tail() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A fable: 6 x 4 [1Q] # Key: .model [1] .model Quarter Cement .mean 1 HWMM 2008 Q3 sample[5000] 2438. 2 HWMM 2008 Q4 sample[5000] 2423. 3 HWMM 2009 Q1 sample[5000] 2140. 4 HWMM 2009 Q2 sample[5000] 2402. 5 HWMM 2009 Q3 sample[5000] 2498. 6 HWMM 2009 Q4 sample[5000] 2483. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Calculate accuracy metrics accuracy_results <- fc %>% accuracy(cement) %>% select(.model, RMSE, MAE, MAPE, MASE) %>% arrange(MASE) accuracy_table <- fc %>% accuracy(test, measures = list( MAE = MAE, MSE = MSE, MAPE = MAPE, CRPS = CRPS, ACF = ACF1 )) accuracy_results %>% inner_join(accuracy_table) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 9 .model RMSE MAE MAPE MASE .type MSE CRPS ACF 1 HWMM 150. 128. 5.47 1.32 Test 22595. 84.5 0.627 2 HW 156. 130. 5.49 1.34 Test 24244. 89.6 0.407 3 HWM 159. 133. 5.60 1.37 Test 25154. 91.1 0.523 4 Holt 197. 171. 7.41 1.76 Test 38713. 116. 0.145 5 Simple 236. 201. 8.44 2.07 Test 55896. 141. 0.102 ``` ::: ::: ## Interpreting the Results Key insights: 1. The Holt-Winters model performs best across all metrics 2. MAPE suggests about 5.7% average forecast error 3. MASE of 0.71 means our forecasts are 29% better than naive ## Visual Verification ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} autoplot(fc, level = NULL) + autolayer(cement, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) + labs(title = "ETS Model Forecast Comparison", subtitle = "Holt-Winters shows closest fit to actual data", y = "Cement Production") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](activity32_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Model Diagnostics We should also check residuals: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ets_models %>% select(HWMM) %>% gg_tsresiduals() + labs(title = "Holt-Winters Residual Diagnostics") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](activity32_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Practical Recommendations 1. **For inventory planning**: Use Holt-Winters due to lowest MASE 2. **When extreme errors costly**: Focus on RMSE which penalizes large misses 3. **For executive reporting**: MAPE provides intuitive percentage interpretation ## Lab Activities ### **Activity 1: Comparing ETS and ARIMA Fundamentals** Fit an ETS(A,N,N) and ARIMA(0,1,1) model, then compare their residuals **Part A:** Fit both models and compare their accuracy using MASE and RMSE **Part B:** Analyze residual diagnostics to determine which model handles autocorrelation better **Prompt:** "Which model shows better residual properties for supply chain forecasting? Justify using ACF plots and Ljung-Box test statistics." --- ### **Activity 2: Transformation Impact Analysis** **Part A:** Implement Box-Cox transformation on the Holt-Winters model using $\lambda = 0.2$ **Part B: (Optional)** Evaluate if transformation improves forecast interval coverage at 95% level **Prompt:** "Does variance stabilization help maintain prediction interval reliability during demand spikes? --- ### **Activity 3: Ensemble Forecasting Strategy** **Part A:** Create equal-weighted average of ETS and ARIMA forecasts **Part B:** Verify if ensemble reduces mean error **Prompt:** "When would an ensemble be particularly valuable for cement production planning? Consider both average and worst-case performance."
